Summary: Establishes the policy of the state with respect to the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
column2: to assume responsibility for overseeing implementations of certain actions required to be initiated prior to the adoption of the Delta Plan. Requires the State Water Resources Control Board to make determinations with regard to instream flow needs for rivers and streams within and outside the Delta
column3: and submit such determinations to the council.

column1: Summary: Establishes the Delta Stewardship Council to advance the coequal goals of assuring a more reliable water supply for the State and protecting
column2: restoring and enhancing the Delta ecosystem and certain values of the Delta. Requires the Delta Independent Science Board to develop a scientific program relating to the management of the Delta. Requires such plan to provide for financing of all programs consistent with specified principles. Requires the council to impose an annual fee on persons diverting waters.

column1: Summary: Relates to the Delta Protection Commission. Requires recommendations of the commission and changes the primary delta zone. Establishes a Delta Investment Fund for economic stability. Enacts a Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Reform Act. Creates a Stewardship Council. Relates to the delta conservation and management plan. Requires the collection of watershed diversion data and the development of new flow criteria. Requires a Delta Watermaster. Appropriates funds for a fish protection demonstration program. Providing a more reliable water supply for the state involves implementation of water use efficiency and conservation projects
column3: desalination
column4: and new and improved infrastructure
column5: including water storage and Delta conveyance facilities.

Summary: Enacts the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Reform Act to establish the Delta Stewardship Council to develop and oversee implementation of a comprehensive Delta management plan. Requires the submission of a certification of consistency to any proposed actions within the boundaries of the Delta or Suisun Marsh. Imposes requirements in connection with the Bay Delta Conservation Plan on the Department of Water Resources. Establishes an independent science board. Appropriates funds for a fish protection program. Providing a more reliable water supply for the state involves implementation of water use efficiency and conservation projects

column5: including water storage and Delta conveyance facilities.

Summary: Prohibits a store from providing a single-use carryout bag to a customer unless the store charges a fee per bag at the point of sale. Exempts certain customers from paying the fee. Summary: Amends existing law which requires a generator of hazardous waste to pay the State Board of Equalization a generator fee for each generator site for each calendar year to be deposited in the Hazardous Waste Control Account. Summary: Requires an urban water supplier to develop and implement a water use efficiency and efficient water resources management plan to reduce residential potable water use in a specified manner or achieve extraordinary water use efficiency. Requires the supplier or regional water management group to report its related progress. Enacts the Comprehensive Urban Water Efficiency Act. Requires the convening of a task force to develop best management practices for commercial and industrial uses to achieve reductions. Relates to efficiency and conservation (including rainwater harvesting).

Solid Waste: Extended Producer Responsibility Program

Summary: Creates the Product Stewardship Act of 2009 and requires the Integrated Waste Management Board to administer the program. Provides environmentally sound product stewardship protocols that encourage producers to research alternatives during the product design and packaging phases to foster cradle-to-cradle producer responsibility and reduce the end-of-life environmental impacts of products. Creates the Extended Producer Responsibility Penalty Subaccount. Requires a recycling market development zone (RMDZ)

Summary: Requires that all existing plumbing fixtures in any residential or commercial real property that are not water-conserving plumbing fixtures be replaced prior to the time of sale or transfer by the property owner with water-conserving plumbing fixtures. Provides exceptions. Requires compliance be included as a condition of escrow for any specified sale or transfer. Requires a seller or transferor to certify that the requirement has been satisfied. Requires a real estate agent to disclose these requirements. Relates to water conservation and efficiency.

Author: Torrico (D) Additional Authors: Coto (D);Lowenthal B (D);Chesbro (D);Blumenfield (D);Block (D);Furutani (D);Price (D);Ma (D);Eng (D);DeSaulnier (D);Beall (D);Skinner (D)

Summary: Establishes the Higher Education Endowment Corporation to annually allocate the moneys in the State Higher Education Fund which this legislation will create. Imposes an oil and gas severance tax upon any producer for the privilege of severing oil and gas from the earth or water in the state at a specified percentage of the gross value of the product. Provides the tax will be administered by the State Board of Equalization and will be deposited into the State Higher Education Fund.

Open-Space Preservation: Urban American River Parkway

Summary: Amends the Bushy Lake Preservation Act regarding the Urban American River Parkway. Requires the State Exposition and State Fair Board to preserve the California Exposition flood plain as an element of the Sacramento County general plan. Authorizes additional parking on Exposition land under the act as long as the total number of parking days does not exceed a specified amount. Deletes provisions authorizing in-line skating on the parkway.

Summary: Repeals a provision limiting the authority of the Public Utilities Commission to require a water corporation to install water meters. Requires a corporation with a specified number of service connections to install a meter on each new connection. Requires each corporation that has installed meters to charge customers for potable water based on the volume of deliveries. Authorizes the commission to require a corporation to install a meter at any connection between the water system and a customer. Relates to water conservation and efficiency.

Summary: Amends existing law that allows urban water suppliers that are members of the Urban Water Conservation Council and submit reports to that council to satisfy that requirement by submitting reports to the Department of Water Resources. Deems water suppliers that are members of the council and comply with the Memorandum of Understanding Regarding Urban Water Conservation in the State to be in compliance with the requirement to describe the supplier's water demand management measure in its urban plan. Relates to urban water management planning. Requires an urban water supplier to describe opportunities for development of recycled water supplies
column2: including nonpotable and indirect potable reuse and stormwater recapture and reuse as a long-term water supply. Requires the department to determine that an urban water supplier is eligible for a water management grant or loan
column3: despite a failure to implement all of the water demand management measures if the supplier submits certain documentation. Water conservation and efficiency.

Solid Waste: Single Use Carryout Bags

Author: Brownley (D) Additional Authors: Leno (D);Lowenthal A (D);Ammiano (D);Chesbro (D);Hill (D);Lowenthal B (D);Perez J (D);Skinner (D);Yamada (D);Feuer (D);DeSaulnier (D);De Leon (D);Ruskin (D);Nava (D);Evans (D);Hancock (D);Torlakson (D);Liu (D);Pavley (D)

Summary: Repeals at-store recycling programs for single-use carryout bags and the provision preempting local regulatory action. Prohibits certain stores from providing a single-use carryout bag to a customer. Requires those stores to provide reusable bags that meet certain criteria and to make them available for purchase. Requires bag producer fees. Relates to civil penalties for violations. Appropriates funds for grants and loans for jobs in the manufacture and recycling of plastic bags that use recycled material.

column5: purchasing recycled content carpeting and other products
column6: using low volatile organic compound paints
column7: electronically distributing certain documents
column8: and upgrading the fuel efficiency of the vehicle fleet through the purchase of hybrids. Continued projects: Increasing the overall fuel economy and fuel diversity of the vehicle fleet
column9: Improving waste diversion practices
column10: such as material and electronic waste recycling
column12: and reusing materials
column13: Investing in energy efficiency and water conservation technologies
column15: such as green and recycled content products.

Summary: Establishes a $45 income tax credit for beverage containers. This Act establishes a beverage container tax credit to reimburse consumers for the recycling fee lost because of the curbside recycling program. The tax credit for each eligible taxpayer shall be $45. The amount is based on an average household of 2.5 people who each consume one beverage ($.05 cent redemption fee) every day for a year (2.5 x $.05 x 365).

Summary: Applies the solid waste disposal surcharge to all waste that is deposited in a landfill
column3: or waste-to-energy facility
column4: applies the also surcharge to waste that is shipped out of state for disposal
column5: provides that payment is made by the entity doing to the disposal or the entity responsible for preparation for the out-of-state transfer of collected solid waste
column6: provides for collection and transfers of monies. There is established a solid waste management surcharge. The solid waste management surcharge shall be 35 cents per ton of solid waste either disposed of within the state at permitted or unpermitted solid waste disposal facilities and waste-to-energy facilities
column7: or transferred to solid waste reduction facilities within the state that collect solid waste for transport to an out-of-state landfill
column9: or waste-to-energy facility.

column2: provide for the placement of a plastic bag collection bin in each store.

Summary: Relates to transportation of radioactive materials
column2: adds violations concerning the transportation of radioactive waste to the list of violations for which a truck and trailer may be stopped
column3: inspected
column4: and cited at a weigh station. Allows certain members of: (1) local emergency planning committees
column5: (2) the board of firefighting personnel standards and education
column6: appoints designees. This bill requires a person that transports high or low level radioactive waste to obtain a permit from the department of homeland security. It provides that the state police department may detain
column7: seize
column8: or impound a vehicle that illegally transports radioactive waste. It imposes civil penalties for the illegal transportation of radioactive waste. Deposits civil penalties in the nuclear response fund. This bill specifies who may inspect motor vehicles for illegal transportation of radioactive waste and provides that the illegal transportation of radioactive waste is a Class B infraction. Effective: July 1
column9: 2010. An application for a permit to transport high or low level radioactive waste must include the following: a description of the type
column11: and radioactivity of the material being transported
column12: a description of the proposed route and transport schedule
column13: contain an expiration date... Instead of a transportation fee of one thousand dollars ($1
column14: 000) for each cask of nuclear waste in the shipment
column15: the following fee will apply: for each truck shipment
column18: a transportation fee of one hundred dollars ($100) for each total shipment of low level radioactive waste will apply.

Summary: Establishes a wine connoisseur permit. This permit provides that a person may order a total of 12 9-liter cases of wine per year shipped from a specialty wine permit holder by way of a common carrier. The fee for a wine connoisseur permit is $75 per year. This bill also grants routine technical rule-making authority to the Department of Public Safety's division of liquor licensing and compliance to ensure that bottles of wine received under a wine connoisseur permit comply with the bottle deposit law. Status: Pending - Joint Committee on Environment

Summary: Relates to producer responsibility for mercury added lamps. No mercury-added lamp wholesaler shall sell mercury-added lamps unless the wholesaler informs the purchaser in writing on the invoice or another separate document that the lamps contain mercury and that the lamps are prohibited from placement in a solid waste landfill or combustor. Retail establishments that incidentally sell mercury-added lamps are exempt from the requirements of this subsection.

Summary: Urges the Public Service Commission to establish a nuclear waste escrow account to receive funds from electric utility customers. High-level radioactive waste is the spent

column4: 000 metric tons of used spent fuel. Be it resolved by the Senate (the House of Representatives Concurring)
column5: that we urge the Michigan Public Service Commission to establish a nuclear waste escrow account to receive the funds collected from Michigan's electric utility customers

column7: and be it further be resolved
column8: that copies of this resolution be transmitted to chairman of the Michigan Public Service Commission.

column3: Waste and Recycling-Product Stewardship

column1: Summary: Relates to environment, provides for plastic bag recycling. An operator shall establish an in-store recycling program that includes, but need not be limited to, the following: (1) every plastic carryout bag provided by a store must have printed or displayed on the outside face of the bag the words "PLEASE REUSE OR RECYCLE AT A PARTICIPATING STORE," using letters at least one-half inch in height, or a similar message encouraging the reuse or recycling of plastic carryout bags that is no less than one inch in height and uses letters at least one-quarter inch in height, (2) a bin for collection of plastic carryout bags and other film plastic must be placed in a visible location easily accessible to the consumer and must be clearly marked as available for collecting plastic carryout bags and other film plastic for recycling, (3) all plastic carryout bags and other film plastic returned to the store must be collected, transported, and recycled in a manner consistent with this chapter or any rule adopted under this chapter, (4) plastic carryout bags and other film plastic collected by the store that are free of foreign material must not be disposed of in any solid waste or hazardous waste disposal facility, and (5) the operator shall make available to consumers within the store at or near the place where plastic carryout bags are dispensed, reusable bags, which may be purchased and used in lieu of plastic carryout bags or paper bags. Manufacturer responsibilities: (a) A manufacturer whose plastic carryout bags are sold or distributed to a store subject to this section shall make arrangements with the operator, upon the operator's request, for the collection, transport, and recycling of all plastic carryout bags and other film plastic collected consistent with this section. The arrangements may include contracts or other agreements with third parties.

Summary: Concerns hazardous waste transporter fee. This bill would create a quarterly reporting and fee payment cycle for hazardous waste transporters. Under this bill
column2: the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) would establish the hazardous waste transporter fee at least 30 days before the beginning of each new quarterly reporting period. Transporters would pay the fee on a quarterly basis within 30 days after the end of each quarterly period
column3: ending on March 31
column4: June 30
column5: September 30
column6: and December 31. This quarterly schedule will improve the collection of fees by transporters and make the fee payment to the DEP more accurately reflect actual costs
column7: rather than transporters being charged for manifests on a retroactive basis. The bill provides the DEP with the opportunity to adjust the hazardous waste transporter fee quarterly
column9: and the fee may not increase more than $0.50 per ton in any given quarterly reporting period
column10: thus avoiding an abrupt or steep increase in fees in one year. (transportation)

Summary: Relates to the Plastic Carryout Bag and Film Plastic Recycling Act. This bill requires retailers to establish in-store recycling programs that provide opportunities for customers to return clean plastic carryout bags. The bill requires the owner or operator of every retail store to establish an in-store recycling program that provides an opportunity for customers to purchase a reusable bag and return clean plastic bags to that store. The bill requires a plastic bag provided by a store to have specified information printed or displayed on the bag
column2: and requires the placement of a plastic bag collection bin in each store that is visible and easily accessible to the consumer. All plastic bags collected by the store must be collected
column3: transported
column4: and recycled in a manner that does not conflict with the relevant county district recycling plan. The bill requires every manufacturer of plastic bags to develop educational materials to encourage the reducing
column5: reusing
column6: and recycling of plastic bags and to make the materials available to stores.

Summary: Relates to the Plastic Bag Recycling Act. This bill requires retailers to establish in-store recycling programs that provide opportunities for customers to return clean plastic carryout bags. The bill also provides for the eventual phase-out of plastic bags over a three-year period. The bill requires the owner or operator of every retail store to establish an in-store recycling program that provides an opportunity for customers to purchase a reusable bag and return clean plastic bags to that store. The bill requires a plastic bag provided by a store to have specified information printed or displayed on the bag
column2: and requires the placement of a plastic bag collection bin in each store that is visible and easily accessible to the consumer. All plastic bags collected by the store must be collected
column3: transported
column4: and recycled in a manner that does not conflict with the relevant county district recycling plan. The bill requires every manufacturer of plastic bags to develop educational materials to encourage the reducing
column5: reusing
column6: and recycling of plastic bags and to make the materials available to stores. The bill also requires every owner or operator of a store to provide biodegradable plastic bags to customers at the point of sale in accordance with rules and regulations adopted by the Department of Environmental Protection. The bill provides that
column7: by December 31
column9: every owner or operator of a retail store must restrict the use of plastic bags by 50% of the current volume and by December 31
column11: all plastic bags would be banned from use in this State.

column1: Summary: Provides for the recycling of certain electronic equipment and provides for extended producer responsibility. A MANUFACTURER MUST ANNUALLY RECYCLE OR ARRANGE FOR THE COLLECTION AND RECYCLING OF THE NUMBER OF POUNDS OF A MANUFACTURER'S COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES SOLD TO HOUSEHOLDS DURING THE PREVIOUS PROGRAM YEAR MULTIPLIED BY THE PROPORTION OF SALES OF VIDEO DISPLAY DEVICES REQUIRED TO BE RECYCLED
column2: SET AT 0.3 FOR THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR
column3: 0.6 FOR THE SECOND PROGRAM YEAR
column4: AND 0.75 FOR... A MANUFACTURER SHALL SUBMIT WITH THE REPORT REQUIRED UNDER THIS SECTION A DESCRIPTION OF HOW THE INFORMATION OR ESTIMATE WAS CALCULATED. EACH MANUFACTURER MUST REPORT TO THE DEPARTMENT THE TOTAL WEIGHT OF COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES THE MANUFACTURER COLLECTED FROM HOUSEHOLDS AND RECYCLED OR ARRANGED TO HAVE COLLECTED AND RECYCLED DURING THE PRECEDING PROGRAM YEAR. EACH MANUFACTURER MUST SET FORTH IN THE ANNUAL REPORT REQUIRED UNDER THIS SECTION INFORMATION ON THE END MARKETS AND ELECTRONIC RECYCLERS UTILIZED BY THE MANUFACTURER
column5: INCLUDING DETAILS ON THE METHODS OF COLLECTION
column6: HANDLING AND RECYCLING OR REUSE OF COVERED ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT USED BY ELECTRONIC RECYCLERS
column7: DETAILS ON ANY DISASSEMBLY OR PHYSICAL RECOVERY OPERATION TO BE USED
column8: THE LOCATIONS OF ANY SUCH OPERATIONS
column9: AND DETAILS ON THE MANUFACTURER'S COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND REGULATIONS RELATING TO THE DISPOSITION
column10: RECYCLING AND REUSE OF COVERED ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT. BY AUGUST FIRST OF EACH YEAR
column12: A RECYCLER OF COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES SHALL REPORT TO THE AGENCY AND THE DEPARTMENT THE TOTAL WEIGHT OF COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES RECYCLED DURING THE PRECEDING PROGRAM YEAR. A RETAILER WHO SELLS NEW COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES SHALL PROVIDE INFORMATION TO HOUSEHOLDS DESCRIBING WHERE AND HOW THEY MAY RECYCLE COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES AND ADVISING THEM OF OPPORTUNITIES AND LOCATIONS FOR THE CONVENIENT COLLECTION OF COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES FOR THE PURPOSE OF RECYCLING. THIS REQUIREMENT MAY BE MET BY PROVIDING THE DEPARTMENT'S TOLL-FREE NUMBER AND WEBSITE ADDRESS. RETAILERS SELLING THROUGH CATALOGS OR THE INTERNET MAY MEET THIS REQUIREMENT BY INCLUDING THE INFORMATION IN A PROMINENT LOCATION ON THE RETAILER'S WEBSITE.

column1: 04/17/2009 - To SENATE Committee on STATE GOVERNMENT.
Status: Pending - Senate Environmental Resources and Energy Committee
Author: Boscola (D) Additional Authors: Costa J (D);O'Pake (D);Rafferty (R);Fontana (D)
Summary: Amends the Municipal Waste Planning
column2: Recycling and Waste Reduction Act. Defines affected municipality. Further provides for Powers and duties of the Department of Health and for host municipality benefit fee. Authorizes an affected municipality benefit fee. Provides for effect of multiple violations. Makes editorial changes. The host municipality fee is $1 per ton of weighed solid waste or $1 per three cubic yards of volume-measured solid waste for all solid waste received at a landfill or facility. The affected municipality fee is 50 cents per ton of weighted solid waste or 50 cents per three cubic yards of volume-measured solid waste for all solid waste received at a landfill or facility. Any amounts paid by an operator to a host municipality or affected municipality pursuant to a preexisting agreement shall serve as a credit against the fee amount imposed by this section.

Summary: Amends the Solid Waste Management Act. Provides that no permit shall be issued for the siting of a new municipal waste landfill or the expansion of an existing municipal waste landfill in a municipality where a referendum has been conducted. Provides that prior to the approval of an application for a permit to operate a municipal waste landfill or a permit to expand
column2: the county board of elections shall conduct a binding referendum in the host municipality and all affected municipalities.

column3: Waste and Recycling-Product Stewardship

column1: Summary: Establishes a recycling program for certain covered devices. Imposes duties on manufacturers and retailers of certain covered devices. Provides for the Powers and duties of the Department of Environmental Protection and for enforcement. Prescribes penalties. A manufacturer shall establish
column2: conduct and manage a plan to collect
column3: transport and recycle a quantity of covered computer devices equal to the manufacturer's return share in weight or
column4: in the case of covered television devices
column5: the manufacturer's market share. The plan shall be submitted to the department for review. A group of manufacturers may submit a joint plan to collect
column6: transport and recycle the sum of the return shares in weight in the case of covered computer devices of each participating manufacturer or
column7: in the case of covered television devices
column8: the television manufacturer's market share. The department shall: (1) Maintain an Internet website and toll-free telephone number complete with up-to-date listings of where consumers may take covered computer devices or covered television devices for recycling under this act. (2) No more frequently than annually and no less frequently than biennially
column9: review at a public hearing the amount of the covered computer device and covered television device recycling and registration fee. Recommended changes to the covered computer device and covered television device recycling program and registration fees shall be included in the annual report. No manufacturer or retailer may charge a fee or cost to a consumer for the collection
column10: transportation or recycling of a covered electronic device or a covered television device.

column1: Summary: Proposes to enact a solid waste program under which producers of solid waste designated by the secretary of natural resources would be required to pay for and implement a program for the collection
column3: and disposition of designated solid wastes
column4: including certain types of packaging. Vermont has endorsed expanded producer responsibility as the preferred policy for managing specific electronic waste
column5: mercury-containing waste
column6: and other specific categories of waste. Extending EPR requirements to all packaging and printed material can result in a solid waste management system that diverts in excess of 60 percent of these wastes from Vermont's landfills. While Vermont's bottle bill diverts a high percentage of those beverage containers included under the regulation
column7: this has resulted in the development of parallel recycling systems for beverage containers and for other recyclable packaging and printed materials. Maintaining two parallel recycling systems results in unnecessarily high costs for consumers
column8: significantly increased vehicle traffic to recycling centers
column9: and a higher carbon footprint for the state. Requirements on solid waste districts and municipalities. Within one year of approval of a program plan for printed material and packaging
column10: municipalities and solid waste districts shall implement mandatory recycling requirements for these designated wastes and shall implement pay-as-you-throw pricing for household waste collection and disposal.

Release of Mercury Into the Environment

Summary: Reduces the release of mercury into the environment. The legislature finds that: (1) Convenient and environmentally sound product stewardship programs for mercury-containing lights that include collecting
column3: and recycling mercury-containing lights will help protect Washington's environment and the health of state residents
column4: (2) Mercury lighting is a toxic and hard to collect waste product that is appropriate for product stewardship
column5: (3) The purpose of this act is to achieve a statewide goal of recycling all end-of-life mercury-containing lights by 2020 through expanded public education
column6: a uniform statewide requirement to recycle all mercury-containing light bulbs.

column2: the purpose of this act is to promote public recycling and prevent unnecessary waste of recyclable materials. In communities where there is an established curbside service and where recycling service is available to businesses
column3: a recycling program must be provided in the same place and the same quantities wherever solid waste or litter receptacles are located. A recycling program includes provision of receptacles or reverse vending machines

column6: and plastic.

column20: and video recorders used by individuals. The bill also provides for shortfall fees.
